subject: Re: [junit] About @DataPoint and @ Theory
msgSnippet: There is an issue open for this feature request: http://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/issue/78 Vote up if you agree with the suggested runDiscretely
messageBody:
There is an issue open for this feature request:

http://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/issue/78

Vote up if you agree with the suggested "runDiscretely" option.

Brett

On Wed, Apr 28, 2010 at 3:43 AM, rionard_zhao <prettyrlr@...> wrote:

>
>
> Hi,
> I'm a developer of my company's test framework. Recently, i'm so interested
> in the usage of @DataPoint and @Theory.
>
> I want to use @DataPoint to provide different parameters for one @Theory
> test, and i hope my test framework can handle each compatible @DataPoint for
> the @Theory test as the independent test to run. I hope everyone of this
> kind test can generate their own "Assertion Success" or "Assertion Fail".
>
> For example:
> @DataPoint
> public static int testInt = 77;
> @DataPoint
> public static String testStr1 = new String("Test string 1!");
> @DataPoint
> public static String testStr2 = new String("Test string 2!");
> @DataPoint
> public static String testStr3 = new String("Test string 3!");
>
> @Theory
> public void testDataPoint(String tempStr){
> System.out.println("Now string is " + tempStr);
> assertEquals("Two strings are not matched!", "Test string 1!", tempStr);
> }
>
> I hope "testDataPoint" can run three times with testStr1, testStr2,
> testStr3 in our test framework. But it fails.
>
> It seems that JUnit4(4.4-4.8.2) handles the @Theory test as only one test
> no matter how many compatible @DataPoint parameters there are. And it will
> fail the test once an Assertion Fail generate, then, stop here and ignore
> the left @DataPoint parameters.
>
> Now for one test, we need different parameters to run, we need assert each
> result, we don't want the test to stop by only one fail result, we want to
> see all results by one time run.
>
> So, I hope whether you can change Junit4 internally to satisfy this
> requirement, I think it will provide more convenience for every tester.
>
> Thank you,
> Rionard Zhao
>
>
>
